title: 107_hr3041
content: The "Travel America Now Act of 2001" may be cited as the short title for this legislation. The findings section of the Act highlights key points related to its purpose. Prior to September 11, 2001, the travel and tourism industry in the United States employed over 19 million people with a payroll of $171.5 billion. In 2000, the industry generated over $582 billion in expenditures and $99.6 billion in tax revenues. Additionally, it created a $14 billion trade surplus for the country. Post-9/11, efforts are being made to ensure the safety and security of travel. Following the 9/11 attacks, the travel industry is working with the government to ensure safe travel and maintain traveler confidence. Urgent measures are needed to support workers and generate cash flow for the industry's economic stability. Increased consumer spending on travel is crucial for the US economy's recovery, encouraging both personal and business travel to stimulate economic growth. SEC. 25C. PERSONAL TRAVEL CREDIT is a new section added to the Internal Revenue Code to provide a credit for personal travel expenses. The new section added to the Internal Revenue Code allows individuals to claim a credit for qualified personal travel expenses incurred before January 1, 2002. The maximum credit is $500 for individuals and $1,000 for joint returns. Qualified personal travel expenses include transportation and lodging costs for qualifying personal trips. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code allows individuals to claim a credit for qualified personal travel expenses incurred before January 1, 2002. Qualifying personal trips include travel within the United States, involving an overnight stay at a commercial lodging facility, with the farthest destination being at least 100 miles from the taxpayer's residence. The credit covers expenses for transportation by aircraft, rail, watercraft, or motor vehicle, as well as lodging at commercial facilities. It does not include expenses for meals, entertainment, amusement, or recreation. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code allows individuals to claim a credit for qualified personal travel expenses incurred after the enactment date. Qualifying trips involve an overnight stay at a commercial lodging facility, excluding expenses deductible for business or income-producing activities. Commercial lodging facilities include hotels, motels, resorts, rooming houses, or campgrounds. No credit is allowed for dependents. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code allows individuals to claim a credit for qualified personal travel expenses incurred after the enactment date. Qualifying trips involve an overnight stay at a commercial lodging facility, such as hotels, motels, resorts, rooming houses, or campgrounds. No credit is allowed for dependents, and expenses must be substantiated with adequate records. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code allows individuals to claim a credit for qualified personal travel expenses incurred after the enactment date. No deduction is allowed for expenses if a credit is claimed under this section. The amendment allows for a temporary increase in the deduction for business meals and entertainment expenses, changing the limit from 50% to 100% for expenses incurred between the enactment date and January 1, 2002. This amendment applies to taxable years ending after the enactment date of the Act. SEC. 5. Net operating loss carryback for travel and tourism industry. The amendment allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for 5 years preceding the loss year. The amendment allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for 5 years preceding the loss year. Special rules for travel and tourism industry losses are outlined in the Internal Revenue Code, defining terms and limitations for net operating loss deductions. The amendment allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for 5 years preceding the loss year. The term 'travel or tourism business' includes various activities related to travel and tourism such as transportation, lodging, airport operations, travel agency services, and entertainment facilities. The provision allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for 5 years. It includes activities like transportation, lodging, airport operations, travel agency services, and entertainment facilities. Coordination with specified liability losses is required, and taxpayers can elect to adjust the carryback period. Taxpayers in the travel and tourism industry can elect to adjust the carryback period for losses without regard to certain regulations. Additionally, these losses can be credited against taxable income earned during the 5-year carryback period by related taxpayers in a controlled group of corporations. Taxpayers in the travel and tourism industry can adjust the carryback period for losses and credit them against taxable income earned by related taxpayers in a controlled group of corporations. The amendments apply to taxable years before, on, or after the enactment of the Act. The Act is based on Congress's power to levy taxes as outlined in article I, section 8 of the US Constitution.
